metadata.title: ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï (Daughter)
metadata.subject: Marathi
metadata.description: A powerful Marathi poem celebrating the birth and value of a daughter. The poem uses rich metaphors: '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ / ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' ‚Äî daughter is red gold, green tattoo, new leaf on a tree, and sandalwood from the bones. The poem also describes the daughter as the grandfather's inherited qualities and the grandmother's favourite. It ends with a powerful message of gender equality: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (Boy and girl are equal, give both respect). A chapter about values, poetry, and social equality.

preAssessment.question: What is the Marathi word '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' (lek) used to mean?
In the poem, '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' compares a daughter to:

options.C: New leaf / fresh shoot on a tree

preAssessment.question: What is the key message of the poem about gender equality?

options.B: Boys are more important than girls
options.C: Girls and boys are equal ‚Äî both deserve equal respect

preAssessment.question: What is '‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (gondaN) in the poem's metaphor '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£'?

concepts.title: The Poem and Its Social Message
concepts.content: The poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' celebrates the birth and existence of a daughter in language that is so rich and beautiful that it directly counters the deep-rooted problem of female foeticide (the practice of aborting female foetuses because daughters are not wanted). In Maharashtra and across India, many families historically preferred sons ‚Äî daughters were seen as a burden (because of dowry demands, perceived lower social value). This poem powerfully says: a daughter is not a burden ‚Äî she is gold, a tattoo, a new leaf, sandalwood, the family's treasure. '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' in Marathi can mean child generally, but in this context it means specifically daughter. The poem's message is: welcome and celebrate every daughter.

examples.text: The poem's richness of metaphor says: a daughter is not just 'okay' ‚Äî she is gold, precious, beautiful, and essential.
Maharashtra's female child sex ratio has historically been a concern ‚Äî poems and campaigns like this counter that trend.
The poem says a daughter is '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (new leaf) ‚Äî fresh growth, hope, and renewal for the family.
The ending message ‚Äî '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (boy and girl are equal) ‚Äî is a direct social declaration.

keyPoints: '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' means child, but in this poem it specifically celebrates daughters.
The poem counters the social problem of female foeticide and son preference with powerful positive imagery.
Maharashtra had/has issues with skewed female-to-male sex ratios, especially in some districts.
The poem uses rich metaphors to say: a daughter is MORE valuable than people realize ‚Äî she is gold, new life, precious.
The closing message '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (boys and girls are equal) is a powerful declaration for gender equality.
concepts.funFact: The Government of India launched 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' (Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter) in 2015, primarily in Maharashtra, Haryana, and Rajasthan ‚Äî states where the female-to-male birth ratio was most imbalanced. This poem in the school textbook is part of the same cultural movement to change mindsets about daughters!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 11, Pages 37-41 ‚Äî Maharashtra Board 7th Grade Marathi (Second Language)

concepts.title: Metaphors for Daughters in the Poem
concepts.content: The poem uses four powerful metaphors in its opening: (1) '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' ‚Äî red/pure gold (‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = refined pure gold, ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç = red/warm coloured, associated with auspiciousness). Daughter = precious, pure, like gold. (2) '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' ‚Äî green tattoo (‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ = traditional decorative tattoo design on the body, ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç = green, associated with life/fertility). Daughter = permanent mark on the family, like a beautiful tattoo that stays forever. (3) '‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' ‚Äî new leaf on a tree (‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä = fresh shoot or new growth). Daughter = new life, renewal, hope, freshness. (4) '‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' ‚Äî sandalwood of the bones (‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = sandalwood ‚Äî deeply fragrant, precious, used in worship). Daughter = fragrance that comes from the deepest part of the family.

examples.text: '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' (red/pure gold): Daughters are as precious as the finest pure gold ‚Äî invaluable and beautiful.
'‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (green tattoo): A daughter is permanently and beautifully part of the family ‚Äî like a tattoo that lasts forever.
'‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (new leaf on a tree): A daughter is fresh growth ‚Äî she brings new life, hope, and energy to the family.
'‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' (sandalwood from bones): Like sandalwood ‚Äî the more you rub it, the more fragrance it gives. A daughter gives more the more you involve her in family life.

keyPoints: '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' = red pure gold ‚Äî daughter is precious and pure like the finest gold.
'‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' = green tattoo ‚Äî daughter is permanent, beautiful, part of the family forever.
'‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' = new leaf/shoot on a tree ‚Äî daughter represents fresh hope and new life.
'‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' = sandalwood from bones ‚Äî deepest, most essential fragrance of the family.
All four metaphors communicate: a daughter is not a burden but a treasure ‚Äî precious, permanent, life-giving.
concepts.funFact: ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ (tattoo/traditional body art) is an ancient tradition in Maharashtra's tribal and rural communities. Women from the Gondi, Koli, and Mahadeo Koli communities traditionally wore elaborate ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ designs on arms and faces as identity markers. The poem's use of this image connects daughter-love with deep Maharashtra cultural traditions!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 11, Pages 37-40 ‚Äî Metaphors in the poem

concepts.title: Gender Equality ‚Äî ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®
concepts.content: The poem ends with one of the most direct statements of gender equality in Marathi poetry: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' ‚Äî 'Boy and girl are equal; give respect to both.' This simple, powerful couplet is a direct rejection of the idea that daughters are less valuable than sons. '‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = equal (‡§è‡§ï = one, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® = same/equal). '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = respect/honour (‡§∏‡§§‡•ç = good + ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® = esteem). Gender equality (‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ) is a fundamental value in democratic societies and is protected by India's Constitution ‚Äî every child, regardless of gender, has equal rights to education, safety, and opportunity.

examples.text: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' ‚Äî both deserve the same education, opportunities, safety, and love.
Equal education rights: Article 21-A of India's Constitution guarantees education for all children aged 6-14, regardless of gender.
Maharashtra has many examples of women excelling in sports: Saina Nehwal, P.V. Sindhu, Mary Kom ‚Äî all proving gender equality in achievement.
'‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = respect ‚Äî real gender equality is not just legal rights but also social respect and recognition.

keyPoints: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' ‚Äî the poem's climactic message of gender equality.
Article 15 of India's Constitution prohibits discrimination based on gender.
Maharashtra has historically produced great women reformers (Savitribai Phule, Pandita Ramabai) who fought for this equality.
Beti Bachao Beti Padhao campaign (2015) ‚Äî India's government initiative to save and educate girl children.
Real gender equality means: equal education, opportunities, safety, career choices, and social respect.
concepts.funFact: Maharashtra's Chandrayaan-3 mission to the Moon (2023) had many women scientists at ISRO ‚Äî showing the outcomes when girls receive equal education and opportunity. Including: mission specialist Dr. Muthayya Vanitha and others. These women are literally '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (new shoots) of Indian science who grew because they were given equal opportunity!

concepts.title: Vocabulary: ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£, ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®
concepts.content: The poem introduces rich Marathi vocabulary that students should understand: (1) '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' = child (often daughter); (2) '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç' = red/reddish-warm colour (also means auspicious, like the colour of kumkum); (3) '‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' = pure/refined gold (highest quality); (4) '‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' = traditional tattoo/body art; (5) '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' = new leaf/fresh shoot on a tree ‚Äî the first green growth after winter; (6) '‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' = sandalwood ‚Äî fragrant wood used in worship and medicine; (7) '‡§π‡§æ‡§°' = bone; (8) '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = respect/honour; (9) '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ' = grandfather; (10) '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•Ä' = grandmother.

examples.text: ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç = red/warm red. In Marathi culture, red (like kumkum/sindoor) is auspicious and celebratory.
‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = the finest, purest form of gold ‚Äî 24-carat gold used in the best jewelry. Daughters are ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®-precious.
‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä = new leaf shoot ‚Äî the tender, fresh green growth on a bare branch after winter or dry season. Full of hope.
‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = sandalwood ‚Äî one of India's most fragrant and precious woods, used in temple worship and Ayurvedic medicine.

keyPoints: ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç = red (warm, auspicious) | ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = finest pure gold | ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ = traditional tattoo
‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä = new leaf/fresh growth on tree | ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = sandalwood (fragrant and precious)
‡§π‡§æ‡§° = bone | ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® = respect/honour | ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï = child (daughter)
‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ = grandfather | ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•Ä = grandmother | ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨ = family
Understanding these words enriches not just this poem but many Marathi poems and songs.
concepts.funFact: Chandan (sandalwood / ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®) from Karnataka and Mysore is among the world's most expensive woods. It is used in temples (sandalwood paste for God's idol), Ayurvedic medicine, incense sticks (‡§Ö‡§ó‡§∞‡§¨‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä), and perfumes. The famous Mysore Palace in Karnataka is built with sandalwood furniture! In Marathi poetry, ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® always symbolizes the most precious, enduring, and fragrant things.

concepts.title: Women in Maharashtra ‚Äî Historical Context
concepts.content: Maharashtra has the proudest history of women's empowerment in India. Key figures: (1) Savitribai Phule (1831-1897) ‚Äî India's first female teacher, opened the first girls' school in Pune (1848); (2) Pandita Ramabai (1858-1922) ‚Äî Sanskrit scholar, social reformer, women's education pioneer; (3) Tarabai Shinde (1850-1910) ‚Äî wrote 'Stri Purush Tulna' (1882), considered India's first feminist text; (4) Anandibai Joshi (1865-1887) ‚Äî first Indian woman to earn an MD (medical degree) in the USA; (5) Ahilyabai Holkar (1725-1795) ‚Äî ruler of Malwa, one of history's greatest female administrators; (6) Jijabai (Jijamata) ‚Äî Chhatrapati Shivaji's mother, who shaped his character and values.

examples.text: Savitribai Phule ‚Äî walked to school through stone-throwing crowds to teach girls in 1848. Her courage opened education to women.
Anandibai Joshi ‚Äî first Indian woman to get a medical degree (1886, USA) ‚Äî at age 21, pioneering women in medicine.
Ahilyabai Holkar ‚Äî built temples and roads across India, administered justice, beloved ruler. A model of female leadership.
Jijabai ‚Äî Shivaji Maharaj's mother who taught him courage, ethics, and nationalism ‚Äî 'behind every great man is a great mother!'

keyPoints: Maharashtra has the richest tradition of women's empowerment in India ‚Äî multiple 'firsts'.
Savitribai Phule (1831-1897) ‚Äî India's first female teacher; opened first girls' school in Pune, 1848.
Tarabai Shinde ‚Äî wrote India's first feminist text 'Stri Purush Tulna' in 1882.
Anandibai Joshi ‚Äî first Indian woman MD (medical doctor), age 21, University of Pennsylvania, USA.
Jijamata (Jijabai) ‚Äî mother of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj; a symbol of strength and values.
concepts.funFact: Anandibai Joshi from Pune went to America in 1883 to study medicine when she was just 17 ‚Äî without any family support, without money, in a country she had never visited, in an era when Indian women rarely left their homes. She got her MD degree in 1886 but died of tuberculosis at just 22 years old. Maharashtra's women have always shown extraordinary courage!

test.question: What does the metaphor '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' compare a daughter to?

options.B: Pure, refined gold ‚Äî precious and beautiful

test.explanation: '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' = red/warm-toned pure gold (‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = the finest quality refined gold). The metaphor compares a daughter to the most precious, purest form of gold ‚Äî saying she is invaluable and beautiful. '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç' also suggests warmth and auspiciousness ‚Äî the colour of kumkum/celebration.

test.question: The Marathi word '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (paalvi) in the poem means:

options.C: New leaf / fresh shoot on a tree

test.explanation: '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' means new leaf or fresh shoot ‚Äî the tender, fresh green growth on a tree, especially after winter or a dry period. Comparing a daughter to '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' says she represents new life, hope, and renewal for the family ‚Äî just as new leaves signal the return of life to a tree.

test.question: What is the key concluding message of the poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï'?

options.A: Daughters are more important than sons
options.B: Boys and girls are equal ‚Äî give both respect (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®)
options.C: Daughters should be protected at home
options.D: Sons carry on the family name

test.explanation: The poem concludes with the powerful couplet: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' ‚Äî 'Boy and girl are equal; give respect to both.' This is a direct, clear declaration of gender equality ‚Äî the poem's most important message for students and families.

test.question: What does '‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' (chandan) mean?
test.explanation: '‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' is sandalwood ‚Äî one of India's most fragrant and precious woods, used in temples, Ayurvedic medicine, and perfumes. In the poem, the metaphor '‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' says the daughter is like sandalwood that comes from the very bones of the family ‚Äî the deepest, most essential fragrance and value.

test.question: The Marathi word '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (sanmaan) in the poem means:
test.explanation: '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç (good) + ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® (esteem/regard) = respect or honour. The poem asks us to give '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (respect) to both boys and girls equally. This is not just about legal rights ‚Äî it is about genuine social respect, treating daughters as valued, important members of the family and society.

test.question: Who was Savitribai Phule and why is she important in the context of this poem?

options.A: A warrior queen who fought the British
options.B: India's first female teacher ‚Äî she opened the first school for girls in Pune (1848)
options.D: A doctor who treated women patients

test.explanation: Savitribai Phule (1831-1897) and her husband Jyotirao Phule opened India's first school for girls in Pune in 1848. She became India's first female teacher, facing stones and abuse from those who opposed girls' education. Her story perfectly embodies the poem's message ‚Äî daughters deserve education and equal respect.

test.question: What is '‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (gondaN) as used in traditional Maharashtra culture?
test.explanation: '‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' is a traditional form of tattoo or body decoration ‚Äî decorative patterns applied to the skin as a form of identity or beauty. In Maharashtra's tribal and rural communities, elaborate ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ designs on arms and faces were traditional. The poem uses '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (green tattoo) to say a daughter is permanently and beautifully part of the family.

test.question: The poem describes the daughter as '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' ‚Äî what does this mean?

options.B: The grandfather's treasure of qualities/virtues passed down

test.explanation: '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' means 'the grandfather's treasure of qualities' ‚Äî the daughter carries forward the grandfather's best qualities, character traits, and virtues. '‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' = treasure/inheritance. '‡§ó‡•Å‡§£' = qualities/virtues. This shows how daughters are not a break from family heritage but carriers and preservers of it.

test.question: Which Indian government campaign relates directly to the message of this poem?

options.B: Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao (Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter)

test.explanation: 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' (Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter) launched by the Indian government in 2015 directly addresses the problem of declining female birth ratio and girls' education. The poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' has the same message: daughters are precious, equal, and deserving of education and respect. The poem in schools supports the campaign's cultural change goals.

test.question: What does '‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (eksaman) mean in '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®'?

options.B: One is better than the other

test.explanation: '‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = ‡§è‡§ï (one) + ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® (same/equal) = completely equal, the same in value and importance. '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' means 'boy and girl are completely equal' ‚Äî in value, importance, worth, and deserving of respect. This is the poem's final and most powerful message.

keyConcepts: ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï = child / daughter ‚Äî the subject of the poem
‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = pure gold | ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ = green tattoo | ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä = new leaf | ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = sandalwood
‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® = respect/honour ‚Äî both genders deserve equal respect
Gender equality in India ‚Äî Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao campaign
Women of Maharashtra: Savitribai Phule, Pandita Ramabai, Tarabai Shinde, Anandibai Joshi
‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ = traditional Marathi tattoo ‚Äî cultural body art
commonMisconceptions: Students may think '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' only means daughter ‚Äî it means child generally but is used specifically for daughter in this poem's context.
'‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' might be confused with any gold ‚Äî it specifically refers to the FINEST, purest refined gold (24-carat equivalent).
Some students may confuse '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (new leaf/shoot) with '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' (leaf) ‚Äî ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä specifically means NEW, fresh growth, while ‡§™‡§æ‡§® is a general leaf.
'‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' may be confused with '‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä' (henna) ‚Äî both are body decoration but ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ is a permanent tattoo tradition, while ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä is temporary.
realWorldExamples: Beti Bachao Beti Padhao: Launched in 2015 in Maharashtra, Haryana, and Rajasthan ‚Äî where sex ratio at birth was most imbalanced.
Savitribai Phule Pune University ‚Äî named after Maharashtra's first female teacher, a daily reminder of women's contributions.
PV Sindhu, Sania Mirza, Mary Kom ‚Äî women sports stars who prove what '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä' (girl) can achieve with equal opportunity.
Maharashtra's 'Ladki Bahin Yojana' (2024) ‚Äî state government scheme to support women financially, based on the same principle of valuing daughters.

interactiveElement.title: Unscramble the Word!
interactiveElement.description: Rearrange the letters to form the correct Marathi vocabulary word.

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: What does the metaphor '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' compare a daughter to?
qaCards.answer: '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' = red/warm-toned pure gold (‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® = the finest quality refined gold). The metaphor compares a daughter to the most precious, purest form of gold ‚Äî saying she is invaluable and beautiful. '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç' also suggests warmth and auspiciousness ‚Äî the colour of kumkum/celebration.

qaCards.question: The Marathi word '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (paalvi) in the poem means:
qaCards.answer: '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' means new leaf or fresh shoot ‚Äî the tender, fresh green growth on a tree, especially after winter or a dry period. Comparing a daughter to '‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' says she represents new life, hope, and renewal for the family ‚Äî just as new leaves signal the return of life to a tree.

qaCards.question: What is the key concluding message of the poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï'?
qaCards.answer: The poem concludes with the powerful couplet: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' ‚Äî 'Boy and girl are equal; give respect to both.' This is a direct, clear declaration of gender equality ‚Äî the poem's most important message for students and families.

qaCards.question: What does '‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' (chandan) mean?
qaCards.answer: '‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' is sandalwood ‚Äî one of India's most fragrant and precious woods, used in temples, Ayurvedic medicine, and perfumes. In the poem, the metaphor '‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' says the daughter is like sandalwood that comes from the very bones of the family ‚Äî the deepest, most essential fragrance and value.

qaCards.question: The Marathi word '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (sanmaan) in the poem means:
qaCards.answer: '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç (good) + ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® (esteem/regard) = respect or honour. The poem asks us to give '‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (respect) to both boys and girls equally. This is not just about legal rights ‚Äî it is about genuine social respect, treating daughters as valued, important members of the family and society.

qaCards.question: Who was Savitribai Phule and why is she important in the context of this poem?
qaCards.answer: Savitribai Phule (1831-1897) and her husband Jyotirao Phule opened India's first school for girls in Pune in 1848. She became India's first female teacher, facing stones and abuse from those who opposed girls' education. Her story perfectly embodies the poem's message ‚Äî daughters deserve education and equal respect.

qaCards.question: What is '‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (gondaN) as used in traditional Maharashtra culture?
qaCards.answer: '‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' is a traditional form of tattoo or body decoration ‚Äî decorative patterns applied to the skin as a form of identity or beauty. In Maharashtra's tribal and rural communities, elaborate ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ designs on arms and faces were traditional. The poem uses '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (green tattoo) to say a daughter is permanently and beautifully part of the family.

qaCards.question: The poem describes the daughter as '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' ‚Äî what does this mean?
qaCards.answer: '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' means 'the grandfather's treasure of qualities' ‚Äî the daughter carries forward the grandfather's best qualities, character traits, and virtues. '‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' = treasure/inheritance. '‡§ó‡•Å‡§£' = qualities/virtues. This shows how daughters are not a break from family heritage but carriers and preservers of it.

qaCards.question: Which Indian government campaign relates directly to the message of this poem?
qaCards.answer: 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' (Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter) launched by the Indian government in 2015 directly addresses the problem of declining female birth ratio and girls' education. The poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' has the same message: daughters are precious, equal, and deserving of education and respect. The poem in schools supports the campaign's cultural change goals.

qaCards.question: What does '‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (eksaman) mean in '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®'?
qaCards.answer: '‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' = ‡§è‡§ï (one) + ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® (same/equal) = completely equal, the same in value and importance. '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' means 'boy and girl are completely equal' ‚Äî in value, importance, worth, and deserving of respect. This is the poem's final and most powerful message.

longAnswers.question: What does the metaphor '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' compare a daughter to?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The metaphor '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' beautifully compares a daughter to pure, refined red gold. In Marathi culture, '‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' refers to the finest quality of gold, while '‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç' represents a warm, auspicious red colour. Through this metaphor, the poet emphasizes that a daughter is an invaluable treasure who brings warmth and beauty to the family. It highlights her immense worth, countering any negative societal views about the birth of a girl child.
keyPoints: '‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®' means pure, refined, and highly valuable gold.
'‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§Ç' signifies a warm, red colour associated with auspiciousness.
The metaphor portrays a daughter as a precious and beautiful treasure.
It emphasizes the high value and importance of a girl child in the family.

longAnswers.question: What is the key concluding message of the poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï' concludes with a powerful and direct message of gender equality: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (Boy and girl are equal, give respect to both). This line strongly rejects the traditional preference for sons over daughters. It urges society to recognize that daughters hold the same value as sons and deserve equal opportunities, education, and respect. Ultimately, the poem serves as a cultural call to celebrate and empower every girl child.
keyPoints: The poem advocates for complete gender equality ('‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®').
It urges society to give equal respect ('‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®') to both boys and girls.
The message directly counters the social issue of son preference.
It highlights the importance of equal rights, education, and opportunities for daughters.

longAnswers.question: How does the poem use the metaphors of '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' and '‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' to describe a daughter?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The poem uses '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' (green tattoo) to describe a daughter as a permanent and beautiful mark on the family, much like traditional body art that stays forever. Additionally, '‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' (new leaf on a tree) represents fresh growth, symbolizing the new life, energy, and hope that a daughter brings. Together, these metaphors show that a daughter is not a temporary burden, but a lasting source of renewal and joy. They paint a vibrant picture of a girl child deeply rooted in the family's happiness.
keyPoints: '‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£' represents a traditional tattoo, showing that a daughter is a permanent part of the family.
'‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä' means a new shoot or leaf, symbolizing fresh hope and new life.
These metaphors counter the idea that a daughter is a burden meant to leave the family.
They highlight her role as a continuous source of joy, energy, and renewal.

longAnswers.question: Who was Savitribai Phule and why is she important in the context of this poem?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Savitribai Phule was a pioneering social reformer and India's first female teacher, who opened the first school for girls in Pune in 1848. Her immense courage in fighting against societal norms paved the way for women's education in Maharashtra and across India. In the context of the poem '‡§≤‡•á‡§ï', her legacy perfectly embodies the message of giving daughters equal rights and respect. Her life's work proves that when daughters are educated and empowered, they can transform society.
keyPoints: Savitribai Phule was India's first female teacher and a champion for women's education.
She opened the first girls' school in Pune in 1848 despite facing severe opposition.
Her work aligns with the poem's core message of gender equality and respecting daughters.
She represents the historical strength and potential of women in Maharashtra when given equal opportunities.

longAnswers.question: The poem describes the daughter as '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' ‚Äî what does this mean?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The phrase '‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' means that a daughter is the treasure house of her grandfather's virtues and good qualities. '‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' refers to a precious inheritance, while '‡§ó‡•Å‡§£' means moral qualities or characteristics. This line beautifully illustrates that a daughter carries forward the family's deepest values and heritage to the next generation. It emphasizes that daughters, just like sons, are true inheritors and preservers of a family's legacy and traditions.
keyPoints: '‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡§æ' means a precious treasure or inheritance.
'‡§ó‡•Å‡§£' refers to the good qualities, virtues, and character traits of the grandfather.
It shows that a daughter preserves and carries forward the family's core values.
The phrase highlights that daughters are proud inheritors of the family's cultural and moral legacy.
